title: Several astronomical events to be visible from Miami Valley
description: Are you curious about what’s happening beyond our atmosphere?
content:
Are you curious about what’s happening beyond our atmosphere?

It’s incredible, really. Starting tonight and running through the end of the month, there are a handful of astronomical events you can catch sight of.
• None 1 in custody after county-wide call for help issued in Montgomery County
• None Owner of dog that attacked 89-year-old, killed pet speaks out
• None Man found in sewer drain after large search forces shelter-in-place in Montgomery County

The Perseid meteor shower hits its peak tonight, August 12-13, bringing with it a torrent of shooting stars along with the potential for spectacular fireball sightings.

The shower coincides with the rise of a waning gibbous moon, the glare from which will make it a challenge to spot all but the brightest of meteors.

The best time to spot Perseids will be in the predawn hours of Aug. 13, when up to 100 shooting stars per hour can be visible. You can start after 10 p.m. in areas with little light pollution.

Very early on Tuesday morning, Aug. 12, also brings the Jupiter and Venus conjunction.

The two planets will be less than a degree apart — approximately the length of your pinkie when held up to the sky at arm’s length. Because they’ll appear close together, you’ll be able to view both simultaneously through your backyard telescope.

And last, but DEFINITELY not least: now through the 31st will be the Grand Planetary Alignment.

A rare celestial event where Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, Uranus, Neptune, and Saturn will align in the sky in a beautiful planetary lineup. Look toward the eastern horizon just before sunrise. Find a dark-sky location, away from city lights, for the clearest view.

Rain chances are limited with the next cold front that is forecast to move toward the Miami Valley over the next 24 hours.

It begins to stall and leaves us with scattered rain and storm chances, mainly on Wednesday afternoon and evening.

The increased cloud cover and bright moon bring us some difficulty, but it’s worth heading out and staying up an extra hour past bedtime to see the beauty of our solar system.
summary: The Perseid meteor shower is set to peak on August 12-13, bringing with it a torrent of shooting stars and potential for spectacular fireball sightings. The best time to spot these meteors will be in the predawn hours of August 13, when up to 100 shooting stars per hour can be seen. The Jupiter and Venus conjunction will also occur early in the morning of Aug. 12, with Jupiter, Venus, Uranus, Neptune, and Saturn aligning in the sky. The Grand Planetary Alignment will occur throughout the month, a rare celestial event where Mercury, Jupiter, and Venus will align in the same way.
shortSummary: The Perseid meteor shower, Jupiter/Venetian conjunction, and the Grand Planetary Alignment will be visible from the Miami Valley, with best viewing conditions in the predawn hours of Aug.
argos_summary: Starting tonight, several astronomical events will take place, including the peak of the Perseid meteor shower, which can produce up to 100 shooting stars per hour in the predawn hours of August 13. Additionally, a conjunction of Jupiter and Venus will occur early on August 12, allowing viewers to see both planets close together. Throughout the month, a rare Grand Planetary Alignment featuring Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, Uranus, Neptune, and Saturn will also be visible, best seen just before sunrise in dark-sky locations.
